frameDefinitions: Using Evidence, which may or may not be expressed, a Cognizer recognizes or proves that Concept1 is associated causally or collocationally with another concept, Concept2.
An Item is attached by a Handle, via a Connector, to a Goal, or Items are attached to each other.
The Connector is an artifact created to affix a Connected_item or to bind onto a Fixed_location and is primarily so used.
An Agent performs a series of unspecified tasks to plan for an Event to take place at a Scheduled_time and Place.

The Attaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically connected to something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be connected to each other.
A Concept_1 is related to Concept_2 by some Evidence.
frameExamples: My thumb was <t>stuck</t> to the tube of glue.
A waterproof <t>adhesive</t> should be used for this exterior job.
I've <t>arranged</t> a breakfast meeting for you tomorrow morning with Mr. Huntsberger.
The robber <t>tied</t> Harry to the chair.
The single remaining piece of evidence <t>linked</t> Kirov the tailor to Kirov the dissident activist.
listRoleDefinitions: <fen>Concept1</fen> is the phenomenon which is believed to be related to <fen>Concept2</fen>.
The phenomenon which is believed to be linked to Concept1.
The sentient entity that recognizes the causal connection.
The phenomena which are believed to be related.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> make the connection.
The location where the Cognizer makes the connection.
<fen>Connector</fen> identifies the instrument used to attach and is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
<fen>Item</fen> identifies the entity that comes to be attached to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Items</fen> identifies the plural items that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which the <fen>Item</fen>(s) is attached.
<fen>Connector</fen> identifies the entity or substance that forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a 'with'-PP.
The person who makes arrangements for the <fen>Event</fen> to take place at a <fen>Time</fen> and <fen>Place</fen>.
The incident for which the <fen>Agent</fen> has made arrangements.
The time for which the <fen>Agent</fen> has arranged the <fen>Event</fen>.
This role describes the time at which the arrangements are made.
The location at which the <fen>Agent</fen> has made arrangements for the <fen>Event</fen> to take place.

The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  It is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> attaches to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> is attached.
The <fen>Connector</fen> forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects an <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
The concept which is linked to <fen>Concept_2</fen>.
The concept which is tied to <fen>Concept_1</fen>.
The phenomenon that points to or proves the connection between <fen>Concept_1</fen> and <fen>Concept_2</fen>. Generally expressed as an external.
The two concepts expressed jointly.
listRoleExamples: The tarp is  tied down <fex>with a rope</fex>.
<fex>A handle</fex>  was affixed to the door.
<fex>The boats</fex> remained tied together.
The boat remained anchored <fex>to the coastline</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair with a <fex><t>rope</t></fex>.
<fex>Lucy</fex> organized a playdate for little Michael and Marcy.
I've already made <fex>vacation</fex> arrangements.
I've put together a luncheon <fex>for 12:30</fex>.
Lionel organized a meeting <fex>at the local pub</fex> to discuss the bleak future of our organization.
<fex>The robber</fex> tied Harry to the chair.
The robber tied <fex>Harry</fex> to the chair.
The robber tied Harry <fex>to the chair</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair  <fex>with a rope</fex>.
The robber tied <fex>Harry's ankles</fex> together.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>at midnight</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>in the basement</fex>.
High death rates among smokers connect <fex>cigarettes</fex> with disease.
Skid marks on the street connects my neighbor's car <fex>to my broken mailbox</fex>.
<fex>Footprints</fex> connect her to the crime.
Ample evidence is able to connect <fex>the two</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Inside the Secret Underworld That's Conspiring to Islamize America
the International Assessment and Strategy Center
the People's Liberation Army Air Force
